list: This survey collects real-time information on issues impacting your business and the economy, to help inform decisions
Questions are updated regularly to reflect important topics, such as the coronavirus (COVID-19) impacts, the end of the EU transition period and climate change.
Your response helps ensure your business, and businesses like yours, are represented.
On average it takes 20 minutes to complete this survey once you have collected the information.
View the latest publication produced from this survey

content.description: Thank you for completing this survey at this challenging time.
View the questions before you start the survey

list: Information should relate to the UK.
We will treat your information securely and confidentially.
This survey is refreshed every two weeks.
To avoid losing data and to help us provide real-time information please submit by the return by date, or at the latest before the next fortnightly survey goes live.
You can save a copy of your answers at the end of this questionnaire using the ‘Download as PDF’ button.

content.description: This section asks for general information on the business's trading status.
This section asks for information on any changes to the business's:

list: turnover in the last two weeks and expectations for the next two weeks
profits in the last two weeks

content.description: This section asks for information about the business's exporting activities and any related challenges. It also asks for information about using rules of origin when exporting.
This section asks for information about the business's importing activities and any related challenges.
This section asks for information about CE and UKCA markings.

These are markings that apply to a wide range of consumer and industrial goods such as toys, personal protective equipment, and construction products. The markings signal that products are fit to be placed on the GB market.
This section asks for information about:

list: the availability of materials, goods and services within the EU
the intention to open branches or subsidiaries in the EU

questions.question: Prices of materials, goods and services

content.description: This section asks for information on any changes to the prices and demand of goods and services bought or sold by the business in the last two weeks.

questions.question: Sending goods to or from Northern Ireland

content.description: This section asks for information about sending goods from GB to Northern Ireland, as well as from Northern Ireland to GB, and any related challenges.
Include
Goods sent to:
GB means ‘Great Britain’ which includes England, Scotland and Wales, but excludes Northern Ireland.
This section asks for information about:
This section asks for information about your workforce such as the:

list: percentage, for example, on furlough leave or working from home, or made redundant in the last two weeks
percentage returning from furlough or homeworking
expected redundancies in the next three months

content.description: It also asks about safety measures in the workplace and future site closures.
This section asks for information about the characteristics of your workforce.
We are asking these questions to help understand how workforce characteristics may have changed across different sectors.
This section asks for information about contact tracing  and the use of the NHS QR code scheme.
Examples of collecting customer, staff or visitor details for contact tracing include:

list: using an online advanced booking system
using the official NHS QR code posters

content.description: It also asks about support your business might have received from local authorities.

blocks.title: Trading status of your business
blocks.description: This section asks for general information on the business's trading status.

questions.title: Which of the following statements best describes {{ metadata['ru_name'] }}'s trading status?
questions.description:
You can interpret 'trading' as 'operating'.

Only select "paused trading"if all trading or operations have temporarily stopped.

blocks.title: Exporting
blocks.description: This section asks for information about the business's exporting activities and any related challenges. It also asks for information about using rules of origin when exporting.

questions.title: Has {{ metadata['ru_name'] }} exported goods or services in the last 12 months?
Which of the following best describes your business's exporting status?

options.label: Never exported and do not have goods or services suitable for export
options.value: Never exported and do not have goods or services suitable for export

options.label: Never exported but have goods or services that could be developed for export
options.value: Never exported but have goods or services that could be developed for export

options.label: Not exported in the last two weeks
options.value: Not exported in the last two weeks

options.label: Not been able to export in the last two weeks
options.value: Not been able to export in the last two weeks

questions.title: Have you experienced any of the following challenges with exporting goods or services in the last two weeks?

options.label: Additional paperwork
options.description: For example, customs declarations, conformity assessments, health and rules-of-origin certifications

options.label: Basing some staff in an EU member state to be allowed to work
options.value: Basing some staff in an EU member state to be allowed to work

options.label: Change in transportation costs
options.description: For example, freight rates

options.label: Closure of infrastructure used to export goods or services
options.value: Closure of infrastructure used to export goods or services
options.description: For example, ports or shipping-container storage facilities

options.label: Customs duties or levies
options.description: Including VAT and other taxes

options.label: Destination countries changing their border restrictions
options.value: Destination countries changing their border restrictions

options.label: Lack of hauliers to transport goods or lack of logistics equipment
options.value: Lack of hauliers to transport goods or lack of logistics equipment
options.description: For example, containers, warehouse capacity or wooden palettes

options.label: Reduced demand for products and services
options.value: Reduced demand for products and services

options.label: Work permit or visa restrictions, or lack of mutual recognition of professional qualifications
options.value: Work permit or visa restrictions, or lack of mutual recognition of professional qualifications

options.label: Did not experience any challenges with exporting
options.value: Did not experience any challenges with exporting

values: Did not experience any challenges with exporting

options.label: End of the EU transition period

questions.title: Does your business currently use rules of origin to access lower or zero tariffs on exports?

definitions.title: What we mean by "rules of origin"

content.description: This is the criteria used to determine where a product was made. They exist in all Free Trade Agreements to ensure only goods made in countries that are part of the agreement can benefit from lower tariffs.

options.label: Yes, to both EU and non-EU countries
options.value: Yes, to both EU and non-EU countries

values: Yes, to both EU and non-EU countries

questions.title: How has using rules of origin when exporting to the EU changed the amount of administration for your business?

content.description: This is referring to gathering the information and completing the paperwork to prove goods comply with rules of origin.

questions.title: Why does your business not currently use rules of origin to access lower or zero tariffs?

options.label: Administrative costs of rules of origin outweigh the potential tariff saving
options.value: Administrative costs of rules of origin outweigh the potential tariff saving

options.label: Exports do not meet rules of origin requirements
options.value: Exports do not meet rules of origin requirements

options.label: Lack of understanding, staffing or expertise to use rules of origin
options.value: Lack of understanding, staffing or expertise to use rules of origin

options.label: My business has attempted to use rules of origin but has been unsuccessful
options.value: My business has attempted to use rules of origin but has been unsuccessful

options.label: The EU does not charge tariffs on the goods the business exports
options.value: The EU does not charge tariffs on the goods the business exports

blocks.title: UK Conformity Assessed (UKCA) marking
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about CE and UKCA markings.

These are markings that apply to a wide range of consumer and industrial goods such as toys, personal protective equipment, and construction products. The markings signal that products are fit to be placed on the GB market.

questions.title: Does your business manufacture, import, or distribute products that require either a CE marking or the new UKCA marking?

definitions.title: What we mean by 'CE and UKCA markings'

content.description: The UKCA (UK Conformity Assessed) marking is a new UK product marking that is used for goods being placed on the market in GB. It covers most goods that previously required the CE (Conformity with European health, safety, and environment) marking.

options.label: Yes, we manufacture products that  need a CE or UKCA marking
options.value: Yes, we manufacture products that  need a CE or UKCA marking

options.label: Yes, we import products that need a CE or UKCA marking
options.value: Yes, we import products that need a CE or UKCA marking

options.label: Yes, we distribute products that need a CE or UKCA marking
options.value: Yes, we distribute products that need a CE or UKCA marking

options.label: No, we do not manufacture, import or distribute products that need a CE or UKCA marking
options.value: No, we do not manufacture, import or distribute products that need a CE or UKCA marking

values: No, we do not manufacture, import or distribute products that need a CE or UKCA marking

questions.title: Are you aware that most CE marked products need to be UKCA marked from 1 January 2022?
Is your business using, or intending to use, the UKCA marking by 1 January 2022?

options.label: Not aware of, or do not know how to meet, requirements for the UKCA
options.value: Not aware of, or do not know how to meet, requirements for the UKCA

options.label: Not using the UKCA marking, but plan to by 1 January 2022
options.value: Not using the UKCA marking, but plan to by 1 January 2022

options.label: Will not use UKCA marking, as not relevant to our products or business
options.value: Will not use UKCA marking, as not relevant to our products or business

blocks.title: Supply chains
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about:

  • any changes to supply chains
  • the availability of materials, goods and services within the EU
  • the intention to open branches or subsidiaries in the EU

questions.title: Has {{ metadata['ru_name'] }} made changes to supply chains due to the end of the EU transition period?

definitions.title: What we mean by the "end of the EU transition period"

content.description: The transition period was when the UK was no longer a member of the EU but continued to be subject to EU rules and remained a member of the single market and customs union. This ended on 31 December 2020. For further information about the transition go to GOV.UK/transition

questions.title: Were these changes to supply chains made as a result of a new UK trade agreement?
In which of the following ways has your business changed supply chains due to the end of the EU transition period?

definitions.title: What we mean by the "end of the EU transition period"

content.description: The transition period was when the UK was no longer a member of the EU but continued to be subject to EU rules and remained a member of the single market and customs union. This ended on 31 December 2020. For further information about the transition go to GOV.UK/transition

options.label: Using more EU suppliers
options.description: Excluding the UK

options.label: Using more non-EU suppliers
options.description: The rest of the world, excluding EU and UK

options.label: Moving the supply chain away from the short straits crossings
options.value: Moving the supply chain away from the short straits crossings
options.description: "Short straits"are the Euro tunnel and ferry routes between the Port of Dover and Calais, Coquelles or Dunkirk

options.label: Expanding to different modes of freight
options.value: Expanding to different modes of freight
options.description: For example, roll-on/roll-off ferries, lift-on/lift-off flights, air freight or rail freights

questions.title: Has your business had any extra costs due to the end of the EU transition period?

options.label: Costs associated with changing supply chains
options.value: Costs associated with changing supply chains

options.label: Costs associated with the storage of goods
options.value: Costs associated with the storage of goods

options.label: Costs due to increased red tape
options.value: Costs due to increased red tape
options.description: For example, customs and rules of origin paperwork

options.label: Cost of setting up EU subsidiaries
options.value: Cost of setting up EU subsidiaries

options.label: Extra costs in the prices of goods and services imported
options.value: Extra costs in the prices of goods and services imported
options.description: Pre-tax or pre-tariff

questions.title: Was your business able to get the materials, goods or services it needed from the EU in the last two weeks?

options.label: Yes, the business has been able to get the materials, goods or services it needed
options.value: Yes, the business has been able to get the materials, goods or services it needed

options.label: Yes, but the business had to change suppliers or find alternative solutions
options.value: Yes, but the business had to change suppliers or find alternative solutions

options.label: No, the business has not been able to get the materials, goods or services needed
options.value: No, the business has not been able to get the materials, goods or services needed

questions.title: Does your business intend to open any new branches or subsidiaries in the EU in the next 12 months?

content.description: This refers to companies owned or controlled by another company, sometimes referred to as the parent or holding company.

values: Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks

questions.title: Would these new branches or subsidiaries be for any of the following?

values: Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks

sections.title: Sending goods to or from Northern Ireland

groups.title: Sending goods to or from Northern Ireland

blocks.title: Sending goods to or from Northern Ireland
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about sending goods from GB to Northern Ireland, as well as from Northern Ireland to GB, and any related challenges.

Include

Goods sent to:

  • other businesses
  • other parts of your business
  • individual customers

GB means ‘Great Britain’ which includes England, Scotland and Wales, but excludes Northern Ireland.

GB means ‘Great Britain’ which includes England, Scotland and Wales, but excludes Northern Ireland.

blocks.title: Access to financial support
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about:

  • cash reserves
  • confidence in business survival
  • insolvency risk

questions.title: How long do you think your business's cash reserves will last?
How much confidence does your business have that it will survive the next three months?
What is your business's risk of insolvency?

content.description: This is where a business cannot pay its debts when they are due or the business owes more than it owns.

questions.title: How has your business's risk of insolvency changed in the last two weeks?

blocks.title: Operational performance
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about your workforce such as the:

  • percentage, for example, on furlough leave or working from home, or made redundant in the last two weeks
  • percentage returning from furlough or homeworking
  • providing regular coronavirus testing
  • expected redundancies in the next three months

It also asks about safety measures in the workplace and future site closures.

questions.title: In the last two weeks, approximately what percentage of {{ metadata['ru_name'] }}'s workforce were:
questions.description:
Your answers need to add up to 100%.

If your workforce did not fall into any of the top five categories, enter "0", then use the "Other"box at the bottom to bring the total to 100%.

Rough estimates are acceptable.

answers.label: On partial or full furlough leave
answers.description: Under the terms of the UK Government's Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS)

answers.label: Working at their normal place of work
answers.description: Include those who were normally homeworkers before the pandemic

answers.label: Working from home instead of at their normal place of work
answers.description: Exclude those who were normally homeworkers before the pandemic

answers.label: On sick leave or not working due to coronavirus (COVID-19)  symptoms, self-isolation or quarantine

values: Currently trading and have been for more than the last two weeks
Started trading within the last two weeks after a pause in trading
Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks

questions.title: Of those partially and fully furloughed, what percentage are fully furloughed?
questions.description: "Fully furloughed"refers to workers who are not working any of their normal hours and who you are claiming for under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS).

content.description: Exclude furloughed staff who are working some hours. These staff are considered "partially furloughed"

definitions.title: How you might answer this question

content.description: If your answer to the previous question was that 80% of your workforce were on partial or full furlough leave, and all of these are on full furlough, then the answer would be 100%. If half of the 80% were on full furlough leave, and the other half partially furloughed, then the answer would be 50%.
A rough estimate is acceptable.

answers.label: Approximate percentage of furloughed staff who are "fully furloughed"
Or select "Not sure"if the percentage is not known or is too difficult to calculate

values: Currently trading and have been for more than the last two weeks
Started trading within the last two weeks after a pause in trading
Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks

questions.title: In the last two weeks, approximately what percentage of your workforce have:
questions.description: Rough estimates are acceptable. Answers do not need to sum to 100.

answers.label: Moved from homeworking  to the normal workplace
answers.description: Exclude those who normally worked from home before the pandemic

answers.label: Moved from the normal workplace to homeworking
Returned from furlough to homeworking, either fully or partially
Returned from furlough to the normal workplace, either fully or partially
Moved from working to furlough, either fully or partially

questions.title: In the next two weeks, approximately what percentage of your workforce will:

answers.label: Move from working to furlough, either fully or partially
Return from furlough to homeworking, either fully or partially
Return from furlough to the normal workplace, either fully or partially
Return to the workplace from homeworking
answers.description: Exclude those who normally worked from home before the pandemic

options.label: Adjusted working practices

questions.description: A risk assessment does not have to be written down if the business employs less than five people.

options.value: Has not been reviewed since being completed

questions.title: Is your business providing regular coronavirus (COVID-19) testing for its workforce?

content.description: Include:
Exclude:

definitions.title: What we mean by "regular coronavirus (COVID-19) testing"

content.description: This means that the business is testing the workforce on a routine basis (for example, once a week) to check for COVID cases, regardless of whether workers are asymptomatic

questions.title: What percentage of your workforce are receiving regular coronavirus (COVID-19) testing?

answers.label: Approximate percentage of your workforce receiving regular testing
Or select "Not sure"if the percentage is not known or is too difficult to calculate

options.label: Automation

blocks.title: Workforce characteristics
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about the characteristics of your workforce.

We are asking these questions to help understand how workforce characteristics may have changed across different sectors.

questions.title: Since the start of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, how has the number of workers from within the European Union (EU) at your business changed?

content.description: Exclude those from  the UK (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland)

options.label: Number of workers from within the EU has increased
options.value: Number of workers from within the EU has increased

options.label: We employ workers from within the EU, and the number has stayed the same
options.value: We employ workers from within the EU, and the number has stayed the same

options.label: Number of workers from within the EU has decreased
options.value: Number of workers from within the EU has decreased

options.label: Not relevant, as have not employed workers from within the EU
options.value: Not relevant, as have not employed workers from within the EU

content.description: Exclude those from  the UK (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland)

options.label: Number of workers from outside the EU has increased
options.value: Number of workers from outside the EU has increased

options.label: We employ workers from outside the EU, and the number has stayed the same
options.value: We employ workers from outside the EU, and the number has stayed the same

options.value: Number of workers from outside the EU has decreased

options.value: Not relevant, as have not employed workers from outside the EU

blocks.title: Contact tracing
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about contact tracing and the use of the NHS QR code scheme.

Examples of collecting customer, staff or visitor details for contact tracing include:

  • using an online advanced booking system
  • using pen and paper
  • using the official NHS QR code posters
  • using computers or tablets

It also asks about support your business might have received from local authorities.

questions.title: Is {{ metadata['ru_name'] }} collecting, or intending to collect, contact details for the purpose of contact tracing at your sites?
questions.description: Dependent upon your business type this may involve collecting contact details from customers, staff or visitors.

content.description: Contact tracing is a procedure used to help prevent the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19). Contact tracing aims to identify and alert people who have come into contact with an infected person.

guidance.show_guidance: Why are we asking this question?
guidance.hide_guidance: Why are we asking this question?

content.description: We want to understand how legislation might be impacting contact tracing procedures for businesses.

questions.title: Which of the following methods is your business using, or intending to use, to collect details for contact tracing?

content.description: QR codes are a quick and secure way to collect contact details for the purpose of contact tracing.

options.label: Commercial QR codes
options.description: QR codes designed and implemented by the business

options.label: Digital records
options.description: For example, using tablets

options.label: Official NHS QR code posters
options.description: Unique QR codes provided by the NHS to be scanned with the NHS COVID-19 app

questions.title: Why is your business not intending to collect details for contact tracing?

options.label: Not a legal requirement for my industry
options.value: Not a legal requirement for my industry

options.label: Not enough people use the NHS COVID-19 app
options.value: Not enough people use the NHS COVID-19 app

options.label: Our business does not want to take part
options.value: Our business does not want to take part

options.label: Unsure of how the data is used or stored
options.value: Unsure of how the data is used or stored

questions.title: Which of the following would encourage your business to use the NHS COVID-19 app QR code posters?

definitions.title: What we mean by "NHS COVID-19 app QR code"

content.description: Businesses in England and Wales can register for a unique NHS QR code that allows visitors, customers and staff to 'check-in' by scanning the code on a mobile device using the NHS COVID-19 app.

options.label: Greater understanding of how data is used and stored
options.value: Greater understanding of how data is used and stored

options.label: Displaying an NHS QR code poster was a legal requirement for my industry
options.value: Displaying an NHS QR code poster was a legal requirement for my industry

options.label: Increased use of the NHS COVID-19 app
options.value: Increased use of the NHS COVID-19 app

options.label: More detailed materials outlining use of QR code
options.value: More detailed materials outlining use of QR code
options.description: For example, informational posters and leaflets for customers

options.label: More information provided to our business
options.value: More information provided to our business

options.label: More support from local authorities and public health teams
options.value: More support from local authorities and public health teams

questions.title: Has your business received any support from your local public health team or local authority in relation to the NHS COVID-19 app QR code posters?

content.description: Include:

list: help setting up the QR code
